transcription.text: [ Music ]
Okay, so networking.
One of the most common questions when asked about Ethereum is how is it different?
How is it different from Bitcoin specifically?
And I think networking is probably one of the areas where Ethereum is significantly different.
So, yeah.
So networking.
What is the network?
Everyone here is a network.
They say that the way that our brains work is a neural network.
So, it only makes sense that we created the Internet, which is also a network, to connect all of us together.
And we've become very dependent on this.
Our economy functions on networks, our cell phones functions on networks, our corporations functions on networks.
And as engineers, we've found ways to define networking and to define its function and to replicate that and to build on top of that.
This is an image of various systems used to power the Internet.
I'm sure everyone here has heard of Ethernet.
Networking equipment, switching equipment, IT operations.
A lot of systems today now run on Ethernet.
And that used to not always be the case.
One interesting story about Ethernet, though, is that --
I'll give a little bit of feedback -- is that it used to be a hub broadcast-based system.
And what this means is that when one device sends out a packet, it goes to all of the devices.
There was no filtering.
There was no -- there were no limitations.
So, if you had a system with 10 devices on it, you'd be fine.
If you went to 100 or 1,000 devices, it just wouldn't work.
Because the network would try and deliver every message to everyone for every packet.
So, to resolve that issue, they came up with switched networks.
And today we have Switch Ethernet.
We also have another virtual layer of Ethernet called VPN -- sorry, VLAN.
And that is used to further allow switch networks to filter and route traffic in a way that can
be optimized for the network that is built for.
So, why is that interesting?
I think that's interesting because I think today with Bitcoin and Ethereum, we are at that stage.
So, with Bitcoin and Ethereum and any kind of distributed peer -- most distributed peer-to-peer
applications, they're broadcast-based.
So, they're either broadcast-based or they're very exclusive in that they are broadcast-based,
but you have a swarm of peers and they're all concerned with a single torrent hash or something.
So, as we move forward, as we define the way that the networking of Bitcoin and Ethereum works,
we're going to begin addressing scalability.
And I think that that's going to look similar to switched networks.
IP, of course, runs on top of Ethernet.
So, this is kind of layered.
We have physical and then adjustability and then application.
And it's kind of a generalized stack of layers.
And Ethereum is built on a network stack that is very similar to this.
So, I'll tell you a little bit about myself real quick.
I've always been into networking, security, picked up programming just after high school,
working at a telecommunications company.
And became very interested in the way that networks work.
So, today, if you were to open your browser, if you were to use your cell phone, if you were to run any kind of application,
it's probably going to connect with TLS.
And this was a case in 2000 with SSL.
When I first started getting into networking and software applications.
So, TLS was previously with SSL.
And its name came from Microsoft agreeing to use a Netscape technology, which is great,
because that's a demonstration of two really amazing technology companies coming together to standardize on encryption.
So, last week, I talked to one of the individuals that worked on TLS and started to explain how I felt about the protocol.
And he said, "Yep, completely agree."
So, when SSL and TLS was created, we did not have some of the strong assertions about cryptography that we have today.
And we didn't have the same computational power than that we had today as well.
So, there's general agreement that what we have now can be improved.
Getting into Ethereum development started chatting with Gavin early last year and started working on the C++ client.
And just prior to that, the telecad released the white paper.
And talking to Gavin, it seemed like we all agreed that
Ethereum could be a great opportunity to improve networking, to improve the general state of things with regard to encryption.
So, if we're going to build out a new network for applications, for smart contracts, let's see if we can also improve the network.
There's an interesting talk by Daniel J. Bernstein, where he presents himself as an employee of Ryzen.
And it's great. If you can find that, it's good to watch, especially if you are in any kind of...
If you work on a system that is built to exchange information, and you are the man in the middle.
So, if you're a telecommunications provider, if you're a bank, if you're operating point of sale systems, anywhere where you have a massive amount of data going through your system,
it's good to actually step back and realize this, and realize that if there's a breach,
you get a lot of value out of being the man in the middle.
But if there's a breach, now maybe you're liable.
But not only that, maybe as we start building decentralized applications,
you may be able to offload that to the network, and both be able to provide value and not have the liability,
so to provide privacy in addition to value.
So, today, networking principally is based on, at a low level, routing information.
So, IP headers have a source and a destination address.
This is really similar to Bitcoin.
So, Bitcoin has a signer, and then it has the destination address and a change address.
And this is very similar to forwarding a packet across the Internet, except you might split the packet in half.
And let's not call it a packet, let's call it a payload.
And so, with Bitcoin, you've basically got all of these payloads being routed through all of these accounts.
And this is very similar to email, except it's secure, and there's some value attached to that transaction.
Ethereum, by the way, we actually do this a little differently. The way that the signature system works,
you can look at it similar to Bitcoin, but it's actually quite different.
You sign the transaction, and the person that wants to verify it, they recover your public key out of the transaction,
and then verify that that's accurate, and then take the information that's been signed.
And then process that.
So, what's significant there is that it's application-oriented instead of networking.
So, applications have a different challenge, and that is discovery.
If you have a network and you're routing information everywhere,
this is very useful, but especially if you can decentralize all of it, right?
So, decentralize all the things, and that's useful.
Well, actually, it turns out it's not.
If you decentralize all the things, and you don't know where all the things are,
your applications can't use the network.
So, what you have to do when you're building your application is in your application,
you have to build something that organizes all of the things that you've decentralized.
So, this is known as routing.
There are DHTs.
There's a lot of technology that can do this in protocols.
And what they basically do is they let you determine exactly where the information is that you need,
and then get you that information.
And this is, again, becoming very different than networking in the past.
With Ethereum, with applications, you will connect to your peers and be able to advertise what you need
or what you're interested in, and then the network will bring it to you.
And this is very useful.
And we have to be careful, though.
We have to build this slowly.
And we have to do it right, because while it can be really useful, and everyone agrees that we need to improve here,
and this general stack of networking and applications, everything talking to each other,
we have to be careful that we don't mess it up.
So, in order to facilitate application networks, we have a network protocol with Ethereum,
for Ethereum nodes, which is encrypted throughout the network, and has a separate node discovery system.
So, quick clarification, node can be anything.
Right now, we have a system for peers who are the nodes to form a network, to be able to broadcast transactions.
And what that gets us today is a stable network for transaction delivery, block delivery, downloads, et cetera.
We've recently added framing, and we'll be adding flow control soon.
And what this means is that you can create a sub protocol that runs on the Ethereum network.
So, go ahead and skip that.
So, we're doing that ourselves, and the sub protocols that we're going to run are, there's ETH for the blockchain,
whisper, which is, and, which is swarm.
You can add your protocol here.
And each one of these protocols is its own set of nodes.
And what this means at the end of the day is that today, everything is a thin client.
So, today, everything is HTML.
And if we wanted to go into Gmail and say, "Okay, I want to send an email, I want to send Bitcoin to one of my contacts."
Or, "I want to sign an Ethereum contract, like, executed Ethereum contract with one of my contacts, I can't really do that."
But, like, there's not an interface in the browser to say, "Okay, execute this function with this application network."
And a lot of times, if you want to actually do that, you have to have a plug-in.
So, what we're going to be building with Ethereum and exposing for your applications is the ability for your applications
to have networks and have networks of networks, which Bitcoin, the Ethereum blockchain, these are networks,
to interface with each other, to pass messages to each other, and to communicate in a way that is not previously available.
So, and that's it.
[Applause]
[Music]
(bells ringing)
[ Silence ]
